chapter.title: Authentication
chapter.para:
A valid Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager username and password must be provided with all invocations on the API, with HTTP Basic Authentication
Basic Authentication is described in RFC 2617 HTTP Authentication: Basic and Digest Access Authentication.
used to encode these credentials. If an invocation on the API does not include an appropriate Authorization header, then a 401 Authorization Required challenge will be issued, as in the message exchange below:

In this case, the request should be re-issued with an Authorization header for the specified realm. The Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager domain and user should be encoded in the supplied credentials via the username@domain convention. So for example given the following user details:
username rhevmadmin
domain domain.example.com
password 123456
unencoded credentials rhevmadmin@domain.example.com:123456
base64 encoded credentials cmhldm1hZG1pbkBibGFjay5xdW1yYW5ldC5jb206MTIzNDU2
we would encode the credentials as shown:
chapter.screen:
HEAD {base} HTTP/1.1 Host: {host} Authorization: Basic cmhldm1hZG1pbkBibGFjay5xdW1yYW5ldC5jb206MTIzNDU2
HTTP/1.1 200 OK ...

note.title: Confidentiality
note.para: Basic authentication involves potentially sensistive information such as passwords being sent in plain text, hence it is recommended that confidentiality is ensured via transport-level encryption.
